content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Search for the most recent paper related to non-commutative geometry submitted by an author with the first name John. Provide the title and the abstract.  Please interact with https://arxiv.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To search for the most recent paper on non-commutative geometry by an author with the first name John, I need to use the search functionality. The main search bar is identified by element [4] (textbox for terms) and [8] (search button). I will input search terms such as "non-commutative geometry John" to maximize relevant results.
Action: Type [4]; non-commutative geometry John
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search failed because I used a generic keyword-based search across all fields. The suggestions on the page recommend using the "Author(s)" field specifically, with the format: surname, forename(s), e.g., "Smith, John". To refine the search, I should use "Advanced Search" and enter "non-commutative geometry" as the topic and an author name in the correct format, such as "John" in the forename field.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I am on the Advanced Search page. To refine the search according to best practices from previous guidance, I need to add an additional search term specifically in the Author(s) field, using the correct format (e.g., John as the forename). I will use the "Add another term +" option to add an author field.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The additional search field has appeared, defaulting to "Title." I should change this field to "Author(s)" so that I can specify the first name "John" following arXiv's best practices for author search, and then enter the name in the textbox to the right.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu for selecting the search field is open. To search for a specific author, I need to select the "Author(s)" option from this dropdown.
Action: Click [16]; Author(s)
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown for the search term type is visible but still set to "Title." I need to explicitly select "Author(s)" to specify the author search.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu is clearly open and ready for a selection. The correct action is to choose "Author(s)" from the dropdown so I can enter an author's name for the search.
Action: Click [16]; Author(s)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown field is still labeled "Title" but is ready for selection. I need to change it to "Author(s)" in order to specify the author's name for the search.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown menu for the search field is still open, and "Author(s)" is visible as a selectable option. Selecting "Author(s)" is necessary to allow an author-specific query.
Action: Click [16]; Author(s)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown for the field type is no longer open, but the area for the second search term is still empty. Now, I should type the author's first name "John" in the new author search field to limit results to papers authored by someone with the first name John.
Action: Type [15]; John
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The query returned no results, likely because the search terms or filters were too restrictive or not appropriately formatted. The terms included an incorrect use of "title=John" instead of attributing "John" to the author field. I need to start a new search and properly separate "non-commutative geometry" as subject/keywords and "John" in the Author(s) field.
Action: Click [13]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I am on the Advanced Search page with empty search fields. To properly search, I should: 
1) Enter "non-commutative geometry" in the first field (set to Title, which is appropriate).
2) Add another term and set it to Author(s). 
3) Enter "John" as the author in the new field.

Next, I need to click "Add another term +" to create a field specifically for the author search.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.7

Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[1]: "member institutions";	[2]: "Donate";	[4]: <input> "Search term or terms";	[5]: "Help";	[6]: "Advanced Search";	[7]: "All fields Title Author Abstract Comments Journal reference ACM classification MSC classification Report number arXiv identifier DOI ORCID arXiv author ID Help pages Full text", "Field to search";	[8]: <button> "Search";	[9]: "Login";	[10]: "Search v0.5.6 released 2020-02-24";	[11]: "Simple Search";	[12]: <input> "";	[13]: "TitleAuthor(s)AbstractCommentsJournal referenceACM classificationMSC classificationReport numberarXiv identifierCross-list categoryDOIORCIDarXiv author IDAll fields";	[14]: "ANDORNOT";	[15]: <input> "";	[16]: "TitleAuthor(s)AbstractCommentsJournal referenceACM classificationMSC classificationReport numberarXiv identifierCross-list categoryDOIORCIDarXiv author IDAll fields";	[17]: <button> "–", "Remove this search term";	[18]: <button> "Add another term +";	[19]: <button> "Search";	[25]: "allastro-phcond-matgr-qchep-exhep-lathep-phhep-thmath-phnlinnucl-exnucl-thphysicsquant-ph";

content:
Thought: The "Add another term" action has been performed, creating a second search field. I need to set the second term (currently set to "Title" in [16]) to "Author(s)" and then input "John" in the corresponding textbox ([15]). This will correctly filter for papers authored by someone named John.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.75
